title: 107_s3088
content: The "Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002" ensures that federal employees in the uniformed services or National Guard will not have their pay reduced while performing active service. The "Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002" guarantees that federal employees serving in the uniformed services or National Guard will not experience a pay reduction during their active duty. The Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002 ensures that federal employees in the uniformed services or National Guard do not face a pay cut during active duty. Amounts payable under this act for each pay period are determined based on the employee's entitlement to reemployment rights and absence from civilian employment without receiving basic pay. The Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002 guarantees federal employees in the uniformed services or National Guard receive their entitled pay during active duty. The act specifies that the amount payable to an employee will be paid by their employing agency from the appropriate fund. The Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002 ensures federal employees in the uniformed services or National Guard receive their entitled pay during active duty. The Office of Personnel Management, in consultation with the Secretary of Defense, will prescribe regulations to implement the provisions of the Act. Agency heads must establish procedures to guarantee employee rights under this section, and the Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration will also create procedures in consultation with the Office. The Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration, in consultation with the Office, will establish procedures to ensure that the rights under the Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002 apply to the employees of the agency. The terms and definitions related to employee rights and service in the uniformed services are specified in the Act. The Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002 defines terms such as employing agency and basic pay, ensuring reemployment rights for employees under chapter 43 of title 38. The table of sections for chapter 55 of title 5, United States Code, is updated accordingly. The Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002 ensures nonreduction in pay for those serving in the uniformed services or National Guard. The effective date for the amendments is pay periods beginning on or after September 11, 2001. Additionally, a new section, SEC. 45G, is added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for Ready Reserve-National Guard employee credit. The Ready Reserve-National Guard employee credit under section 38 allows for a 50% credit of actual compensation for qualified active duty. The maximum credit period is 12 months, and no credit is given for duty on non-work days. The Ready Reserve-National Guard employee is allowed credit for qualified active duty on non-work days. Qualified active duty refers to active duty entitlements for reemployment rights and benefits. The term 'compensation' refers to remuneration for employment deductible from gross income. A Ready Reserve-National Guard employee is a member of the Ready Reserve or National Guard. The terms 'National Guard' and 'Ready Reserve' are defined in title 10, United States Code. The Ready Reserve-National Guard employee credit is added to the general business credit under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code. This credit is determined under section 45G(a) and the definition of Ready Reserve is provided in title 10, United States Code. The Ready Reserve-National Guard employee credit is added to the general business credit under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code, with amendments applying to taxable years starting after December 31, 2001.
